## Package development
The following is a list of Python packages that I have developed or contributed to.

#### Main contributor/ maintainer
| Package | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| [elicito](https://github.com/florence-bockting/elicito/tree/main) | A Python package for learning prior distributions of model parameters based on expert knowledge ([paper](https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.16830)) |
| [gradient-aware-harmonisation](https://github.com/climate-resource/gradient-aware-harmonisation) | A Python package that harmonizes two time series using zero- and first-order gradient information. |
| [GHG-forcing-for-CMIP](https://github.com/climate-resource/GHG-forcing-for-CMIP/tree/main) | Pipeline for constructing a composite greenhouse gas dataset from multiple data sources, including ground-based and satellite observations, suitable for use in climate models participating in the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP). |

: {tbl-colwidths="[20, 50]"}

#### Collaboration, Contribution

| Package | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| [CMIP7-GHG-Concentration-Manuscripts](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP7-GHG-Concentration-Manuscripts) | Python package for writing manuscripts in JupyText and converting it into publishable LaTeX PDF file |
| [input4MIPs_CVs](https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs) | Controlled vocabularies (CVs) used within the input4MIPs project. The CVs define the allowed terms which can be used for various pieces of metadata. |
| [GHG-forcing-for-CMIP](https://github.com/climate-resource/GHG-forcing-for-CMIP/tree/main) | Pipeline for constructing a composite greenhouse gas dataset from multiple data sources, including ground-based and satellite observations, suitable for use in climate models participating in the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP). |
| [CMIP7 ScenarioMIP GHG Concentrations](https://github.com/climate-resource/cmip7-scenariomip-ghg-concentrations) | Generation of GHG concentration inputs (i.e. forcings) for CMIP7's ScenarioMIP.|

: {tbl-colwidths="[20, 50]"}
